message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, weight loss, muscle weakness, and numbness in lower extremities suggest systemic vasculitis. The biopsy of sural nerve reveals transmural inflammation and fibrinoid necrosis of small and medium arteries, which is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa. Remote history of cigarette smoking and Hepatitis B seropositivity are risk factors for polyarteritis nodosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy findings strongly suggest polyarteritis nodosa, which affects small and medium arteries and can cause muscle weakness and numbness in the extremities. The remote history of cigarette smoking and Hepatitis B seropositivity are risk factors for this condition. Microscopic polyangiitis can also cause inflammation of small and medium arteries, but is typically associated with glomerulonephritis. Thromboangiitis obliterans (also known as Buerger's disease) typically affects the small and medium arteries of the extremities and is strongly associated with cigarette smoking. Raynaud disease typically presents with symptoms of cold-induced vasospasm in the fingers or toes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a systemic vasculitis, and the sural nerve biopsy confirms that it is an arteritis. Among the options, only Polyarteritis nodosa fits the description of systemic vasculitis affecting small and medium arteries. Thromboangiitis obliterans affects the distal extremities and Raynaud disease causes vasospasm of the fingers and toes. Microscopic polyangiitis causes a necrotizing vasculitis of small blood vessels, but does not involve medium arteries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a systemic inflammation, and the biopsy findings are typical of polyarteritis nodosa. The history of cigarette smoking and Hepatitis B seropositivity are known risk factors for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy findings suggest Polyarteritis nodosa, which is often associated with Hepatitis B seropositivity. Cigarette smoking as a teenager can also contribute to the development of Polyarteritis nodosa. None of the other options match the biopsy findings and associated risk factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, biopsy results, and past history suggest the most likely diagnosis is Polyarteritis nodosa, which is associated with HBV infection and smoking history. The other options are not associated with these factors and have different presentation and biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the biopsy findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is Polyarteritis nodosa. Hepatitis B infection can cause an immune complex deposition in small- and medium-sized arteries, leading to inflammation and necrosis. Smoking is a known risk factor for Polyarteritis nodosa. None of the other options match the presenting symptoms and biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of transmural inflammation and fibrinoid necrosis of small and medium arteries, along with the chief complaints and history of Hepatitis B seropositivity and smoking, points towards the most likely diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa. Microscopic polyangiitis typically presents with glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis, while thromboangiitis obliterans is typically seen in young male smokers and manifests as peripheral ischemia in the lower limbs. Raynaud disease involves vasospasm of the digital arteries, and does not typically present with the symptoms described in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy findings suggest Polyarteritis nodosa, which is often associated with Hepatitis B seropositivity. Smoking can also be a risk factor for this disease. Microscopic polyangiitis may present with similar symptoms but with few or no immune deposits in blood vessels. Thromboangiitis obliterans affects small and medium arteries mainly in the extremities and is more common in young male smokers. Raynaud disease causes vasospasm in the digits and usually does not present with systemic symptoms like fever and weight loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and sural nerve biopsy suggest systemic vasculitis. Among the options, only Polyarteritis nodosa involves medium-sized vessels and can be associated with Hepatitis B seropositivity. The patient’s history of cigarette smoking can also be a risk factor for this condition.
